section.title: What is PXE booting?
section.para: PXE (Preboot Execution Environment) is a method that allows systems to retrieve bootloaders and OS installers from a network server using DHCP and TFTP or HTTP. It is widely used for provisioning machines without physical media or preinstalled operating systems.

section.title: Benefits of PXE booting
section.para: PXE booting simplifies provisioning by removing the need for local installation media or manual setup. It enables:

listitem.para: Unattended installation of many systems over the network.
Centralized management of installer versions and boot configurations.
Support for diverse architectures and firmware types, including Secure Boot.
Dynamic selection of installers or installation parameters using &grub; menus.

section.title: How PXE booting works in &productname; &productnumber;
section.para: PXE booting in &productname; &productnumber; uses &grub; as the bootloader and the &agama; installer as the installation interface. Bootloaders and installer files are provided over the network using HTTP or TFTP, with &grub; fetching the kernel, initrd and live image. PXE clients can use a variety of firmware (including the most common ones such as BIOS or UEFI), bootloader executable or image formats, as required by their architectures such as &x86-64;, &aarch64;, &ppc64le; and s390x. In addition, they must work in both IPv4 and IPv6 networks.

The bootloader passes kernel parameters such as root=live: to load the squashfs-based root filesystem from a live ISO image, starting the &agama; interface either locally or as a web service for a remote web UI.

section.title: Backward compatibility with &productnameshort; 15.x
section.para: The information in this article applies primarily to &productname; 16.0 and later. It focuses on PXE booting workflows that integrate with the &agama; installer and rely on live installation images. In the context and scope of this article, &productnameshort; 16.0 and later versions differs from &productnameshort; 15.x in the following ways:

listitem.para: Uses dracut and &agama; instead of linuxrc and &yast;.
Use of ISC DHCP is discontinued (EOL 2022). For DHCP server, use any one of Kea or dnsmasq instead.
Uses root=live: or rd.kiwi.* parameters instead of install=.

section.para: The bootloader choice (&grub;, pxelinux, etc.) remains flexible and is not version-dependent.

section.title: How to use the information in this article
section.para: This article consists of mandatory setup steps and optional or alternative configurations. Follow only the sections relevant to your deployment, and skip any alternatives that do not apply to your deployment.

listitem.para: Tasks like installing components, preparing the installer image, configuring &grub;, and validating the server must be completed in all setups.
Choose one: HTTP (recommended with &agama;) or TFTP.
Choose one of dnsmasq, or Kea.
In &productnameshort; &productnumber;, ISC DHCP is discouraged because it has been declared as end of life in 2022 by ISC. For more information, refer to .
Use Kea—the new DHCP server from ISC—as a modern replacement for ISC DHCP. For more information, refer to .

You can use dnsmasq as a combination of a TFTP server, a DHCP server, and a DNS server. In fact, you can use it to serve the bootloader, kernel, initrd over TFTP, and an HTTP server such as nginx to serve other files over HTTP. For PXE boot, nginx is used to serve the the files used in initrd, such as the squashfs.img. dnsmasq provides DHCPv4 options for UEFI HTTPBoot but requires a separate HTTP server such as nginx to deliver the boot files.
Needed if you operate in an IPv6-only or a dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6) network environment.
